p:
The U.S. Influenza Surveillance System
† is a collaboration between CDC and federal, state, local, and territorial partners and uses eight data sources, six of which operate year-round, to collect clinical and laboratory information on influenza. During May 19–September 28, 2019 (surveillance weeks 21–39), public health laboratories in the United States tested 7,637 respiratory specimens for influenza viruses; 1,737 (22.7%) were positive ( Figure 1), including 1,213 (69.8%) for influenza A viruses and 524 (30.2%) for influenza B viruses. Among the 1,154 seasonal influenza A-positive specimens that were subtyped, 324 (28.1%) were influenza A(H1N1)pdm09, and 830 (71.9%) were influenza A(H3N2). Among the 440 influenza B viruses for which lineage was determined, 413 (93.9%) belonged to the B/Victoria lineage and 27 (6.1%) to the B/Yamagata lineage.
